qas.question: What was the third Radio Station in the US?
When was WKY granted a federal license?
When did E.K. Gaylord's Oklahoma Publishing Compan buy WKY Radio?
What is the current station called?

context: Oklahoma City was home to several pioneers in radio and television broadcasting. Oklahoma City's <a0_0>WKY Radio<a0_0/> was the first radio station transmitting west of the Mississippi River and the third radio station in the United States. WKY received its federal license in <a1_0>1921<a1_0/> and has continually broadcast under the same call letters since 1922. In <a2_0>1928<a2_0/>, WKY was purchased by E.K. Gaylord's Oklahoma Publishing Company and affiliated with the NBC Red Network; in 1949, WKY-TV (channel 4) went on the air and later became the first independently owned television station in the U.S. to broadcast in color. In mid-2002, WKY radio was purchased outright by Citadel Broadcasting, who was bought out by Cumulus Broadcasting in 2011. The Gaylord family earlier sold WKY-TV in 1976, which has gone through a succession of owners (what is now <a3_0>KFOR-TV<a3_0/> is currently owned by Tribune Broadcasting as of December 2013).
